It occurs to me - does this need to be a Python class or can it be a `cdef` class?

We can do this. As for necessity - yes, it speeds up the `_does_string_look_like_datetime` in at least 7x (up to 10x), because raising/excepting Python exceptions has a high-enough cost compared to Cythonized functions if your functions are fast.

comments.body:
needs comment explaining that the next three lines are a fancy/fast way to avoid a try/except.

If there is a way to avoid needing `xstrtod` dependency that would help with my pet goal of keeping `tslibs` self-contained.  Definitely don't want to re-implement the entire xstrtod, but might be worth it if xstrtod implements machinery not needed here (e.g. scientific notation)

My original implementation was calling libc `strtod()` with some juggling to get over the fact that Python always uses `.` as decimal point while `strtod` uses locale-dependent one. This added about 50 extra lines of C code that were searching for the decimal point and replacing it with `.` (plus it might've been lacking the removal of thousands separator).

So. while _not_ using `xstrtod()` here is possible, I doubt that it fits the bill of "not increasing complexity" and "not adding new C code" ðŸ˜„ 

P.S. We still need scientific notation here because this function is parsing the input from a user, and who knows how users are storing floats in their data files?..

> We still need scientific notation here because this function is parsing the input from a user

Look at the function in context.  If this pre-check doesn't reject it, it will get passed to other parsing functions, none of which will parse scientific notation into a datetime.

Even if so, what's the point of duplicating the code? There is already optimized C code for parsing floats, why re-implement?
If anything I can only suggest moving it to a separate `.c`/`.h` files under `tslibs` and re-use those in `tokenizer` (which makes some sense, as we might also need some fast integer parsing functions, too). Thoughts?

> There is already optimized C code for parsing floats, why re-implement?

1) If the code in question recognizes formats that we don't want to allow, then it isn't "optimized" for this use case.
2) All else equal, we'd rather code be in cython than in C.
3) To keep the dependency graph simple (Note: I'm at the high end of the caring-about-this scale)

> If anything I can only suggest moving it to a separate .c/.h files under tslibs and re-use those in tokenizer

tokenizer is a mess of its own (in fact I'm pretty sure there are not-quite-duplicate implementations of `xstrtod`) and I'm wary of scope creep in `tslibs`.

> 2\. All else equal, we'd rather code be in cython than in C.

But that C code is _already_ there ðŸ˜„ 



> 3\. To keep the dependency graph simple

So what is your preference here? I don't want to duplicate code for parsing doubles (that is improper practice IMHO), so re-using `xstrtod()` is a very nice thing to do. How do we proceed with it given your feedback?

comments.body: is this really more performant than `int(s)`?  It looks like this is only used if we already know `s` is 4 characters.  I guess we don't know that it is all digits?

If you want microbenchmarks I can try to make those, or you can just take my word on it - `int(s)` is _very_ slow for non-integer strings because it uses Python mechanism of raising and catching exceptions, which itself costs at least 10x more than parsing the integer (because Python has to allocate memory, format error message and walk a list of frames to construct the traceback - everything which would be just thrown away here, because the only fact that we care here is "if it isn't an integer - return `None`").

So a quick measurement shows this (figures are from the benchmark presented in this PR):

sample date| _parse_4digit | int| parse/int ratio
-|-|-|-
03/2010|45.4 ms|54.6 ms|0.83
01/02/2019|17.4 ms|21.8 ms|0.80

Sample implementation:
```cython
cdef inline object parse_delimited_date(object date_string, bint dayfirst,
                                        object tzinfo):
    cdef:
        int day = 1, month = 1, year
        int length = len(date_string)

    if length == 10:
        if date_string[2] not in ' /-\\' or date_string[5] not in ' /-\\':
            return None, None
        try:
            day = int(date_string[:2], 10)
            month = int(date_string[3:5], 10)
            year = int(date_string[6:], 10)
        except ValueError:
            return None, None
        reso = 'day'
    elif length == 7:
        if date_string[2] not in ' /-\\':
            return None, None
        try:
            month = int(date_string[:2], 10)
            year = int(date_string[3:], 10)
        except ValueError:
            return None, None
        reso = 'month'
    else:
        return None, None

    if 1 <= month <= MAX_DAYS_IN_MONTH and 1 <= day <= MAX_DAYS_IN_MONTH \
            and (month <= MAX_MONTH or day <= MAX_MONTH):
        if month > MAX_MONTH or (day < MAX_MONTH and dayfirst):
            day, month = month, day
        return PyDateTimeAPI.DateTime_FromDateAndTime(year, month, day,
                0, 0, 0, 0, tzinfo, PyDateTimeAPI.DateTimeType), reso

    raise DateParseError("Invalid date specified (%d/%d)" %
                            (month, day))
```

I won't say it's much easier, but it's at least 20% slower.
